misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that all resources must be explicitly closed after use, and closing the Scanner connected to standard input (System.in) is standard cleanup procedure, similar to closing a file stream. They likely learned the rule 'close your scanners/streams' but missed the exception regarding System.in.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, closing a `Scanner` object also closes the underlying `InputStream` it is wrapping. When the `Scanner` is attached to `System.in`, closing it effectively closes the standard input stream for the entire application (JVM lifetime). While closing I/O resources is good practice, closing `System.in` can lead to problems if subsequent parts of the program or other classes need to read input, as `System.in` cannot be reopened.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: None in this simple single-class program execution, but it creates potential runtime errors or resource unavailability in larger or sequential programs where `System.in` is needed again.
